awd_titl_txt: Michigan Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (MI-LSAMP)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in their efforts to significantly increase the numbers of students matriculating into and successfully completing high quality degree programs in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines in order to diversify the STEM workforce. Particular emphasis is placed on transforming undergraduate STEM education through innovative, evidence-based recruitment and retention strategies, and relevant educational experiences in support of racial and ethnic groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders. These strategies facilitate the production of well-prepared students highly-qualified and motivated to pursue graduate education or careers in STEM.

For the United States (U.S.) to remain globally competitive, it is vital that it taps into the talent of all its citizens and provides exceptional educational preparedness in STEM areas that underpin the knowledge-based economy. The Michigan Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (MI-LSAMP) was established in 2005 in response to the need for a more diverse and skilled technical workforce. That need still exists and is particularly acute in the State of Michigan. The MI-LSAMP currently consists of four, 4-year institutions (University of Michigan, lead institution; Michigan State University; Wayne State University; Western Michigan University) and two community colleges (Mott Community College and Washtenaw Community College). The goals of MI-LSAMP are to significantly increase the:

1)	Retention and graduation of underrepresented students in STEM bachelor's degree programs via comprehensive support programs and mentored research; 
2)	Number of students from underrepresented racial/ethnic groups transferring to STEM bachelor's degree programs; and 
3)	Number of students from underrepresented racial/ethnic groups pursuing graduate degrees in STEM fields.

These goals support NSF's strategic goal to "cultivate a world-class, broadly inclusive science and engineering workforce, and expand the scientific literacy of all citizens." The goals will be accomplished through activities such as pre-first year summer programs, faculty mentored research, student-to-student mentoring, and a comprehensive 2-year STEM-emphasis transfer program that will include a specialized curriculum and the establishment of a complete wrap-around academic and social support at the community college partner institutions. In addition, the community college students would be afforded the opportunity to participate in a summer bridge program between high school and their first year in community college and then again the summer between community college and transfer to a 4-year institution. The increased engagement with community colleges, greater involvement of faculty mentors from diverse STEM disciplines, and heightened institutional commitment to underrepresented students' well-being and success will produce higher rates of retention and graduation; and moreover, lead to a more talented and diverse STEM workforce.

The knowledge generating research study is focused investigating the community college pathways to STEM Baccalaureate degrees for students from underrepresented racial/ethnic groups in STEM.  The overall supposition is that providing to underrepresented students clear and unobstructed pathways through the college-level STEM curriculum of community colleges into STEM programs at four-year institutions would result in increased STEM baccalaureate degree production.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
The Michigan Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (MI-LSAMP) is composed of six institutions - University of Michigan, Michigan State University, Wayne State University, Western Michigan University, Mott Community College, and Washtenaw Community College. MI-LSAMP goals are to significantly increase the retention and persistence of URM students in STEM baccalaureate degree programs; double the number of community college URM students transferring to STEM degree programs at 4-year partner universities; and increase the number of URM students pursuing graduate degrees in STEM.

Our third phase saw the institutionalization of Pre-First Year Programs (PFYPs); broadening STEM experiential offerings by partnership with a range of STEM academic departments; extending  programs through graduate-level opportunities; merging community college student programming with Alliance 4-year partners; and Alliance-wide standardization. These efforts resulted in 3,543 STEM degrees awarded to URM students across the alliance 4-year institutions, 1,247 URM students transferred to STEM baccalaureate programs across all 4-year partner institutions, and 125 MI-LSAMP students enrolled in graduate school.

From the early years of this phase, MI-LSAMP leadership placed its primary focus on planning and designing an Alliance-wide student cohort-based program to create a larger pool of students for undergraduate research and graduate STEM enrollment. Alliance partners worked to solidify long-term support for PFYPs to continue feeding the pipeline. Mid-phase, MI-LSAMP programs expanded to address students? academic and social needs throughout their undergraduate tenure with initiatives that included faculty-mentored research, personal and professional skills development, international study, and partnerships with a multiplicity of STEM academic departments?another successful institutionalization strategy.

The disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic pushed MI-LSAMP into virtual programming that created Alliance-wide standardization. The NxtGEN STEM Scholars Program, a summer virtual initiative, created the first school-year cohort to receive a standardized STEM programming. NxtGEN involved nearly two hundred participants over two summer sessions, combining asynchronous learning and synchronous collaborative professional development sessions.

Community College (CC) partners have been focused on cohort development from the beginning of Phase 3, implementing a STEM Scholars program which included summer intensives to prepare students for their first two years at the community college, a full academic year of support from staff, administrators and core STEM faculty, and a successful transfer and subsequent two years at one of the Alliance four-year partners. They launched the NxtGEN STEM Scholars Summer Transition Program during COVID to align with the four-year partners. Alliance partner Michigan State University submitted a successful proposal (NSF Proposal #1742381) to support the successful preparation and transfer of our community college partner STEM students to STEM degree programs at MSU. After rigorous academic preparation, students who enrolled in MSU's natural science degree program continued to receive an S-STEM scholarship and joined the College's Charles Drew Science Scholars program, which provides comprehensive academic support, career advising, professional development and a residential Living and Learning Community experience. A partnership with the Michigan Department of Transportation exposes students to related STEM careers with educational presentations, research opportunities and summer internships.

To encourage students to pursue graduate school, MI-LSAMP has provided opportunities for them to attend symposiums and conferences and present the research they have done under faculty mentors engaged through the program. One such in-state opportunity is the Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP). MSU hosts an AGEP Student Success Conference every fall for students across Alliance partners, featuring interactive tracks that explore the graduate school application process, various stages of the PhD journey and faculty opportunities.

Research on URM STEM student success strategies has been a critical component of MI-LSAMP. The Alliance supported the work of a social science researcher located in the U-M School of Education, who conducted embedded research with MI-LSAMP in a knowledge-generating project to identify and create new pathways for CC students to pursue STEM degrees. The Alliance, through its Lead Co-PI, also partnered with the Director of UM's National Center for Institutional Diversity to secure a federal grant (NSF #1008327) to conduct research on African American STEM student achievement pathways.

Finally, MI-LSAMP has worked diligently to disseminate critical information to students, Alliance partner institutions, and institutions of higher education nationally. For students, the Slack platform has proven to be an extremely effective communications and engagement tool. A comprehensive communications strategy has resulted in a new website and social media targeting all stakeholders. MI-LSAMP staff and research partners have published and  presented  conferences across the country, including the Louis Stokes Midwest Regional Center of Excellence, NSF International Center for Excellence, and the "Understanding Interventions that Broaden Participation in Science" Annual Conference.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2021
Modified by: Herbert G Winful
